site_name: F E A R AND CENTER FOR EDUCATION

citations.narrative:
Two enclosures containing nonhuman primates showed areas of excessive rust. In an enclosure for one Sulawesi crested
macaque and one Japanese macaque, there are multiple sections of metal and cage wire by the tunnel into the house
that have rusted through and broken. In an enclosure for one olive baboon, there is a metal pole along the bottom of the
back fence that has rusted through and created a large hole in the pole.
Excessive rust can compromise structural strength, present roughened and jagged surfaces where it is possible for the
animal to injure themselves, and prevent proper cleaning and sanitization of a surface. Any surfaces that come in contact
with the nonhuman primates must be free of excessive rust that prevents the required cleaning and sanitization, or that
affects the structural strength of the surface.
To be corrected by October 31, 2023.

One approximately 2-year-old female olive baboon “Macy” was found deceased in her enclosure on 1/22/2023 after
getting her head trapped in an elastic tie loop which resulted in strangulation. The licensee stated that, prior to use, the
enclosure was checked for anything that could endanger nonhuman primates, including the elastic ties holding down the
tarp at the top of the enclosure but that this one must have been missed.
Inappropriate materials used in primary enclosures can lead to injury or death of the nonhuman primates inside. Primary
enclosures must be constructed and maintained so that they protect the nonhuman primates from injury.
To be corrected from this day (9/29/2023) forward.

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
At the time of inspection, an environment enhancement plan (EEP) has not been established to promote the
psychological well-being of the birds.
Failure to establish and maintain an EEP can result in birds not receiving adequate enrichment which can lead to
behavioral, social, health, and other psychological problems. The plan must address at a minimum social grouping,
environment enrichment, special considerations, restraint devices, and any birds that are exempted by the attending
veterinarian because of health issues or other conditions. The plan must be approved by the attending veterinarian.
Licensee must establish and maintain an EEP for the birds.
To be corrected by October 20, 2023.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
n

narrative:
3.75(c)(1)(i) 
   
Housing facilities, general. 
Two enclosures containing nonhuman primates showed areas of excessive rust. In an enclosure for one Sulawesi crested 
macaque and one Japanese macaque, there are multiple sections of metal and cage wire by the tunnel into the house 
that have rusted through and broken. In an enclosure for one olive baboon, there is a metal pole along the bottom of the 
back fence that has rusted through and created a large hole in the pole.  
 
Excessive rust can compromise structural strength, present roughened and jagged surfaces where it is possible for the 
animal to injure themselves, and prevent proper cleaning and sanitization of a surface. Any surfaces that come in contact 
with the nonhuman primates must be free of excessive rust that prevents the required cleaning and sanitization, or that 
affects the structural strength of the surface. 
 
To be corrected by October 31, 2023. 
3.80(a)(2)(ii)  Critical
   
Primary enclosures. 
One approximately 2-year-old female olive baboon “Macy” was found deceased in her enclosure on 1/22/2023 after 
getting her head trapped in an elastic tie loop which resulted in strangulation. The licensee stated that, prior to use, the 
enclosure was checked for anything that could endanger nonhuman primates, including the elastic ties holding down the 
tarp at the top of the enclosure but that this one must have been missed. 
 
Inappropriate materials used in primary enclosures can lead to injury or death of the nonhuman primates inside. Primary 
enclosures must be constructed and maintained so that they protect the nonhuman primates from injury. 
 
To be corrected from this day (9/29/2023) forward. 
3.154 
   
Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.

At the time of inspection, an environment enhancement plan (EEP) has not been established to promote the 
psychological well-being of the birds.  
 
Failure to establish and maintain an EEP can result in birds not receiving adequate enrichment which can lead to 
behavioral, social, health, and other psychological problems. The plan must address at a minimum social grouping, 
environment enrichment, special considerations, restraint devices, and any birds that are exempted by the attending 
veterinarian because of health issues or other conditions. The plan must be approved by the attending veterinarian. 
Licensee must establish and maintain an EEP for the birds.  
 
To be corrected by October 20, 2023. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
